noun.description: Any of a series of nickel-iron alloys containing approximately 75–78 per cent nickel, 4–6 per cent copper, and 1½–2 per cent chromium by weight, which are used to make transformer cores and magnetic shields because of their high permeability and low hysteresis loss in weak magnetic fields. [A trademark in the United Kingdom.]

origin: 1920s; earliest use found in The Trade Marks Journal. From the name of the Greek letter μ + metal.
